instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00928: What is 820-00928? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PLT_RST_L: What is PLT_RST_L? This is an abbreviation of “PLT_RESET_L” – when you see “PLT_RST_L", assume the person meant to type PLT_RESET_L.
definitions.3V3_S0: What is 3V3_S0? Abbreviation for PP3V3_S0, a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP1V2_S3: What is PP1V2_S3? PP1V2_S3 is a 1.2v power rail present when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state.
definitions.PP1V8_S3: What is PP1V8_S3? The PP1V8_S3 signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides a voltage of 1.8 volts during the S3 power state. The S3 state, often referred to as "suspend to RAM," is a low-power mode where the computer saves the session's state to RAM, allowing for quicker wake-up times compared to a full shutdown..
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A not turning on
threads.message:
Good morning, I have a Mac that won't turn on, no oxidation.

I have taken the following measurements:


<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>: 12.65V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>: 3.4V
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>: 0V ~ 2.8V PULSE
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>: 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PLT_RST_L</SIGNAL>: 0V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A not turning on
threads.message:
If <SIGNAL>3V3_S0</SIGNAL> is stable, <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> should be stable too.
Post voltage for other S3 and S0 voltages, including CPU coils.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A not turning on
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S3</SIGNAL> = 0v, pulsing 1.12V
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S0SW</SIGNAL> = 0V, pulsing 1.003V
<SIGNAL>PP1V0_SUS</SIGNAL> = 1.005V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S3</SIGNAL> = 0V, pulsing 1.73V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S0SW</SIGNAL> = 0V, pulsing 1.8V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> 3.32V

L7410 / 7420 - 0V
L7221 / 7211/7231 - 0V
L7330 - 0V, pulsing 0.8V
LA350 - 0V
LA300 - 0V
L7420 - 0V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A not turning on
threads.message:
Are you sure <SIGNAL>3V3_S0</SIGNAL> is not pulsing?
What about <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> then?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A not turning on
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 71838, member: 682"]
Are you sure <SIGNAL>3V3_S0</SIGNAL> is not pulsing?
[/QUOTE]Sorry, it is pulsing 0V ~ 3.034V.
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> 0V ~2.923V pulsing.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A not turning on
threads.message:
No pulse at all at L7211/21/31?
<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS both steady?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A not turning on
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A not turning on
threads.message:
Looks like no pulse at all at VCORE.
When you have doubts, an o-scope can help you; it catches the peak of any fast pulse.

Did you try SMC bypass mode?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A not turning on
threads.message:
using o-scope:
L7410 40mV
L7420 40mV
L7211 40mV
L7221 40mV
L7231 40mV
L7330 1.08V
LA650 40mV
LA350 40mV
It does not go into SMC bypass mode.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A not turning on
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A not turning on
threads.message:

Here is the link BIOS dump I used.

[URL unfurl="true"]https://drive.google.com/file/d/1k1MRz1mZSnCzn-L54XCNB8hlTXxXsek6/view?usp=sharing[/URL]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A not turning on
threads.message:
Possibly bad CPU.

Did you test the board alone on the desk?
Always pulsing?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A not turning on
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PVCCCORE_PH1_VCC</SIGNAL> oscillates between 0.354V ~ 4.661V . 
I thought it might be <CHIP>U7210</CHIP> and <CHIP>U7420</CHIP>, so I replaced them, but no result.

 I tested it always off the table.

<SIGNAL>PP1V8_AWAKE_SW3C</SIGNAL> 0 ~ 0.881V 
<SIGNAL>PMU_TO_SOC_AWAKE_PWRGD</SIGNAL> 0.170 ~ 0.827 V
<SIGNAL>PP3V0_AWAKE_LDO7</SIGNAL> 0V ~ 1.435V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A not turning on
threads.message: Done T2 restore, it worked, thanks!
